net.smacke.jaydio

Class DirectIoLib

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.smacke.jaydio.DirectIoLib
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    MockDirectIoLib

    public class DirectIoLib
extends Object
    Class containing native hooks and utility methods for performing direct I/O, using the Linux O_DIRECT flag.

    This class is initialized at class load time, by registering JNA hooks into native methods. It also calculates Linux kernel version-dependent alignment amount (in bytes) for use with the O_DIRECT flag, when given a string for a file or directory.

    Author:
    smacke

    • Method Detail

      • getLibForPath

        public static DirectIoLib getLibForPath(String workingDir)
        Static method to register JNA hooks for doing direct I/O

        Parameters:
        workingDir - A directory within the mounted file system on which we'll be working Should preferably BE the directory in which we'll be working.

      • pread

        public int pread(int fd,
        AlignedDirectByteBuffer buf,
        long offset)
          throws IOException
        Interface into native pread function. Always reads an entire buffer, unlike pwrite() which uses buffer state to determine how much of buffer to write.

        Parameters:
        fd - A file discriptor to pass to native pread
        buf - The buffer into which to record the file read
        offset - The file offset at which to read
        Returns:
        The number of bytes successfully read from the file
        Throws:
        IOException

      • pwrite

        public int pwrite(int fd,
         AlignedDirectByteBuffer buf,
         long offset)
           throws IOException
        Interface into native pwrite function. Writes bytes corresponding to the nearest file system block boundaries between buf.position() and buf.limit().

        Parameters:
        fd - A file descriptor to pass to native pwrite
        buf - The buffer from which to write
        offset - The file offset at which to write
        Returns:
        The number of bytes successfully written to the file
        Throws:
        IOException

      • oDirectOpen

        public int oDirectOpen(String pathname,
              boolean readOnly)
                throws IOException
        Use the open Linux system call and pass in the O_DIRECT flag. Currently the only other flags passed in are O_RDONLY if readOnly is true, and (if not) O_RDWR and O_CREAT.
        Parameters:
        pathname - The path to the file to open. If file does not exist and we are opening with readOnly, this will throw an error. Otherwise, if it does not exist but we have readOnly set to false, create the file.
        readOnly - Whether to pass in O_RDONLY
        Returns:
        An integer file descriptor for the opened file
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getLastError

        public static String getLastError()
        Hooks into errno using Native.getLastError(), and parses it with native strerror function.
        Returns:
        An error message corresponding to the last errno

      • blockSize

        public int blockSize()
        Returns:
        The soft block size for use with transfer multiples and memory alignment multiples

      • defaultBufferSize

        public int defaultBufferSize()
        Returns the default buffer size for file channels doing O_DIRECT I/O. By default this is equal to the block size.
        Returns:
        The default buffer size

      • posix_memalign

        public static int posix_memalign(com.sun.jna.ptr.PointerByReference memptr,
                 com.sun.jna.NativeLong alignment,
                 com.sun.jna.NativeLong size)
        Given a pointer-to-pointer memptr, sets the dereferenced value to point to the start of an allocated block of size bytes, where the starting address is a multiple of alignment. It is guaranteed that the block may be freed by calling @{link free(Pointer) on the starting address. See "man 3 posix_memalign".
        Parameters:
        memptr - The pointer-to-pointer which will point to the address of the allocated aligned block
        alignment - The alignment multiple of the starting address of the allocated block
        size - The number of bytes to allocate
        Returns:
        0 on success, one of the C error codes on failure.

      • free

        public static void free(com.sun.jna.Pointer ptr)
        See "man 3 free".
        Parameters:
        ptr - The pointer to the hunk of memory which needs freeing

        See "man 2 close"

        Returns:
        0 on success, -1 on error
